34151976.review:
[i] Что может изменить сущность человека?	[/i]
Planescape:Torment - одна из главных игр Серебряного века РПГ, партийная рпг, классика, которую, бл@дь, знать надо. Если вы такой же слоупок, как и я, и до сих пор в нее не играли, то я вам советую это сделать. Даже так - бросайте все свои дела, чтобы начать проходить этот шедевр, забивайте на хрень, которую сейчас проходите; если у вас предстоит свадьба, то не приходите на нее, сославшись на смертельную болезнь, а сами втихаря задраchивайте днями и ночами в Планшкаф. Потому что это самая бомбезная вещь в моей карьере геймера за последний год точно. 

Эта игра - падла, которая разбудит тебя на три часа раньше, чем ты обычно встаешь, потащит в свой мир, не дав почистить зубы и надеть носки, а после прохождения заставит тебя молиться на разрабов, даже если ты этого никогда не делал и вообще против религии. А ещё она может существенно сэкономить тебе деньги и позволит купить два дошика вместо одного, ведь играя в нее днями напролет, ты даже не вспомнишь, что надо бы купить поeсть.

Сюжет интригует с первых минут. Игрок в роли серого брутального мужика с кучей шрамов и татуировок просыпается в морге на холодной плите и первым делом встречает болтливого черепа Морта.. Первые вопросы: кто я? что я здесь делаю? почему ты летаешь и болтаешь, ошибка неопытного некроманта? Немного придя в себя и заткнув неумолкающую черепушку, мы начинаем разбираться в этой чертoвщине. Вскоре мы узнаем, что главный герой бессмертен, потерял память и не имеет имени. Именно на поиске своей смертности и открытии своих тайн завязан весь сюжет. И это самая крутая завязка, которую я видел. Никакого долбанного спасения мера, никакого предотвращения войны, никакой борьбы с демонами. Просто надо узнать, кто ты такой! Гениально! Сюжет игры очень философский, и после финала (если вы до него дойдете, т.к. игра довольно сложная) вы будете тупо втыкать в монитор, осмысливая все то, что свалилось на вас и ваш мозг во время игры. 

Большую часть игры предстоит читать. Диалоги здесь на каждом шагу, и они реально большие. Полное прочтение диалога со всеми вариантами длится, думаю, в среднем минут 10-15, а есть беседы и на полчаса (некоторые игры за это время проходятся). И если вы видите в начале какого-то диалога всего 2 варианта, то не думайте, что он короткий, т.к. из каждого варианта появятся ещё 3, а из них по 5 новых. Можно, конечно, их пропускать или качать Васю-дурака(кол-во вариантов в диалогах зависит от интеллекта), но какое от этого удовольствие? Вообще, геймплей игры можно описать примерно так: диалог-диалог-диалог-бандиты, вы ничего не попутали?-диалог-диалог-какое красивое колечко, Морт, примерь-диалог-надо бы поспать-диалог-снова бандитам делать нечего.

Боевая система на удивление проста, но бои очень непростые. Во время сражений есть паузы, в которые можно набить пузо персонажей разной целебнoй дрянью и распределить, в какого врага пустить заклинание, а кому просто расцарапать яйца. Сражений сначала немного, но чем дальше, тем их все больше и больше. И тем они трудней, да. Сражаться с демонами в конце игры - это далеко не то же самое, что со скукой раздавать щедрых песделей сигильским бандитам.

Сеттинг о3уенен и 3,14здат. Мир Planescape представляет из себя совокупность планов (т.е. как бы миров), связанных между собой порталами. Чтобы попасть из одного плана в другой, нужно знать местоположение портала и ключ к нему. Ключом может быть что угодно: обычный дверной ключ, тихая песня, похабная мысль о сексуальной Светке с соседнего плана, ржавый меч, аллергический чих. Есть планы внутренние и внешние. Внешние, в свою очередь, делятся на верхние, нижние и нейтральные. Верхние планы - это добрые миры, в которых и жизнь малина, и погода хорошая, и вообще все шик и блеск, а нижние - это обители демонов, дьяволов и прочих мрачных типов, там идет бесконечная Кровавая война между дьяволами баатезу и демонами танар`ри (которая, впрочем, так или иначе затрагивает все планы), и туда вообще соваться не стоит, если дорога жизнь. Нейтральных планов не очень много, они не являются определенно "добрыми" или "злыми"и подвержены либо хаосу, либо порядку. В центре мира находится Сигил - величественный город, город дверей (назван так потому, что в нем куча порталов в другие планы), стоящий на огромном шпиле (уж не знаю, реальный он или воображаемый). 
В этом мире возможно многое. Специально обученные зомби обслуживают посетителей таверны, проклятый маг горит вечность на виду у всех, люди в плащах ходят по улицам в поисках трупов для заработка, а поссав у дерева, ты можешь внезапно очутиться в горах в другом плане.

Planescape: Torment известен своей брутальностью. Можно оторвать себе сердце в обмен на тысячу медяков, попросить старуху-анатомичку покопаться в твоих внутренностях в поисках интересных вещей и получить от нее в подарок кишки в инвентарь, дать голодному бомжу попробовать тебя на вкус, наблюдая, как он кусками отрывает от тебя плоть. Не, ну а че бы и нет? Когда ты бессмертный, надо попробовать все ощущения.

Закончу свой обзор, пожалуй, тем, какие здесь крутые персонажи, преимщественно однопартийцы. Болтливый череп, готовый трахнуть все, что движется, быдлодевка Анна с текстовой эротикой в комплекте, гитцерай Даккон, который дал клятву своему богу и теперь предельно молчалив и послушен, и суккубша, которая изменила своей злой натуре и сделалась этакой доброй дамочкой. Это просто 10 из 10!

34042335.review:
The original Planescape: Torment takes place in a metaphysical fantasy-world inspired by Dante's Divina Commedia. Different planes of existence correspond to the nine different 2nd edition alignments, with good/neutral/evil on one axis and lawful/neutral/evil on the other. In this setting, gods make their homes on planes of existence corresponding with their alignment, mirroring old conceptions of the afterlife. The hub of this universe is the city of Sigil, which is of course associated with neutrality on both axes. Where alignments and gods are the dominating existential aspects of the other planes, Sigil is ruled by a mysterious entity which has banned all gods from entering. In place of religions, there are "factions"; groups with differing existential philosophies vying for followers trying to find a more profound and final meaning to life than just worship of a god, which is central to life outside of Sigil.

In all of this, you drop the protagonist, which is an individual who seemingly lacks the ability to die, but who occasionally suffers from complete memory loss. Your task is to make sense of your predicament against the backdrop of this setting which is sewn together from ideas in theology, philosophy and metaphysics.

If you think this sounds interesting, buy the game. It will be worth your while. It is a bonus if you liked Infinity Engine games such as Baldur's Gate. The Enhanced Edition also has not messed up the original game by retroactively adding modern crap on top, so no worries there.

33897193.review:
[h1]—[i][b]Знай[/b][/i], что когда смерть придет за тобой, её встретит мой клинок. [i][b]Знай[/b][/i], что когда всё вокруг тебя умрёт, я буду жить ради тебя.
— Мы умрем одной смертью, Дак'кон. То будет Речь Двух Смертей Как Одной.[/h1]

Я прошёл эту игру в первый раз только спустя 18 лет после её выхода 
и несмотря на это, играется она очень свежо. Захваывает с первых минут и не отпускает до самого конца. Потрясающий смелый сеттинг, лучшие диалоги и тексты евер.
 Боёвка, конечно, никакая, типа "тактические бои с активной паузой" в теории, а на деле -  диаблоид/мошпит. Всего три класса: вор, воин, маг - все почему то апают экспу с разной скоростью, быстрее всего вор, медленнее всего боец. Мультиклассы только саппортийцы, из ГГ воина-мага не сделать.

 Для полнейшего прохождения нужна мудрость - мастхев для всех классов, без неё пройдя игру вы её на самом деле не пройдёте. И интеллект, параметр сугубо для магов, тоже нужен для правильных ответов, решений и нормального отыгрыша, поэтому получается серьёзный перекос в сторону магов, все гайды по игре советуют играть именно за этот класс, хотя в бою магию я почти не использовал, заклинания бьют слабо, что бы кастануть ещё раз, нужно бежать в таверну и спать 8 часов. Поэтому приятней боёвка за воина, у которого вообще нет никаких скилов, как и у вора. Если что и стоило переделать в ремастере, так это боёвку.

INT and WIS are quite important in this one. It's like a darker more gruesome version of Baldur's Gate. Just not as popular as Icewind Dale or BG. I give it a 8.9/10 would recommend to all RPG fans new and old.

33855286.review:
Planescape Torment è sicuramente un capolavoro nel suo genere in quanto prende le distanze dall'andazzo dei giochi dell'epoca. 
Non ci saranno dungeon e oggetti messi a caso,compagni piatti e stereotipati o esigenze narrative dettate dal caso,tutto è perfettamente coerente dal punto di vista della narrazione della storia che da luoghi,oggetti e npc darà man mano al giocatore più attento sempre un dettaglio in più ,aggiungendo pezzi nel grande puzzle che è la trama,che andando avanti potrebbe rivelarsi fondamentale.
Quasi tutti i personaggi,sopratutto quelli legati al nostro protagonista portano dietro di loro un background che li rende unici e complessi.

L'intero gioco girerà intorno ad una domanda che ricorrà periodicamente nella mente del nostro protagonista e di chi gli sta intorno:"Cosa può cambiare la natura di un uomo?"

L'ambientazione è molto suggestiva e può essere apprezzata appieno da chi conosce D&D, anche se un neofita,dopo la parte iniziale che ha lo scopo di fare sentire il giocatore confuso e pieno di domande potrà trovare le spiegazioni dei vari npc più che sufficienti per capire esattamente dove si trova e come funziona il mondo intorno a se.

Dal punto di vista dei combattimenti può risultare sottotono rispetto a giochi simili come Baldur's gate o Icewind Dale,non presenta la stessa varietà di oggetti unici,magie offensive e un bassissimo numero di possibili compagni,che forzerà svariate decisioni sul come affrontare varie battaglie .L'opportunità di poter evitare praticamente quasi tutti gli scontri principali grazie all'astuzia invece di un più comune è banale "scontro col boss" potrebbe non piacere ad un giocatore più orientato verso un combattimento appagante.

Consiglio dunque l'acquisto ai giocatori che hanno una discreta conoscenza dell'inglese e dei vari slang,amanti del genere e in particolare di trame complesse,prive di stereotipi e deus ex macchina.

33820692.review: "Urf. Ugh. Feels like I've been strained through someone's bowels."

33755179.review:
Ho provato tre o quattro volte a iniziarlo negli anni, ma i colori cupi, la quantità di testo e circostanze varie mi hanno sempre fatto desistere. Qualche tempo fa invece mi ci sono messo seriamente, e oggi l'ho concluso.

Nonostante l'inizio lento, piano piano effettivamente le vicende del Nameless One iniziano a coinvolgere, sempre di più: ogni piccola scoperta evoca nuove domande e conduce a nuovi luoghi e soprattutto nuovi personaggi e nuove storie. Il senso di meraviglia che Torment riesce a evocare è effettivamente, per quanto posso giudicare, ai primi posti nel mondo videoludico: Sigil è un crocevia tra i vari piani di esistenza, e così arriviamo a conoscere di tutto - dalla succube "sensate" che ha lottato contro la sua natura, ai "modroni", esseri meccanici poligonali strutturati in una rigida gerarchia in base alla quantità di facce (ricorda un po' Flatlandia), alla mezzadonna-mezzangelo che narra le sue azioni poeticamente e in terza persona, e queste semplicemente divengono vere, come quando le si chiede se conosce la parola che permette di attivare una caraffa magica.

"Nemelle took it from the stranger, turning in in her hands. Had she seen its like before, she thought? Perhaps... yes, she remembered now. She returned the decanter, whispering into his ear as she did so..." You realize you know the word, now - 'Nildenosaj' - though you're certain the woman never whispered to you, but merely said she did.

La scrittura è eccellente, lo si vede anche dalle piccole frasi. Il costrutto Coaxmetal alla domanda "chi sei?" risponde "I am iron given purpose." Che scopo? "I forge the implements by which the multiverse will be unmade." Musica per le orecchie, non c'è che dire.

La storia è buona, molto buona, anche se credo venga dopo la scrittura, l'ambientazione e il sense of wonder.
Mi ha sorpreso anche la quantità di scelte in continuazione che permettono di imprimere la propria... "tonalità", in una storia che pur complessivamente è lineare. Probabilmente per i giocatori di vecchia data sono cose scontate, ma visto che il mio metro di paragone è, per esempio, Neverwinter Nights 2, mi ha stupito che i personaggi di supporto potessero morire, essere sacrificati per scopi malvagi che si possono coerentemente portare avanti in gioco, o che la loro presenza o meno nel gruppo e il modo in cui ci si rapporta ad essi fa sì che gli eventi vadano in un modo piuttosto che un altro.

Nonostante sia enhanced, si innesta comunque sul gioco base, per cui l'interfaccia lascia a desiderare, la gestione dell'inventario è terribile (massimo 20 oggetti a personaggio, questo è il vero tormento lungo tutto il gioco) e il sistema di combattimento non ha senso, l'ibrido tempo reale / turni non funziona. Ma sono difetti su cui direi che si può tranquillamente sorvolare.

Un difetto più pertinente a ciò per cui il gioco brilla è la difficoltà a seguire questi testi molto lunghi in un inglese che volendo essere poetico e forbito spesso usa parole rare, anche parecchie nella stessa frase; e per converso, molti personaggi parlano con uno slang per cui storpiano le parole, che per un non madrelingua rende molto più lenta e faticosa la lettura.

33748042.review: It's the best game ever, play it.

33727926.review: Wiele gier ma metkę RPG. Niewiele rzeczywiście taką grą jest. To jest gra RPG. Ty decydujesz jakie statystyki ma twój bezimienny. Od tego zależeć będzie nie tylko jak mocno będziesz w stanie przywalić młotem, ale też jak będziesz w stanie poprowadzić rozmowę z poszczególnymi NPCami i jakie opcje będą się przed tobą otwierać. Ta gra nie polega na mordowaniu hord potworów jak większość spod tego szyldu. To poszukiwanie odpowiedzi kim i jakim człowiekiem jest główny bohater a pośrednio kim jesteśmy my wszyscy jako ludzie. Dla inteligentnego człowieka to prawdziwa uczta. Dla młodszych graczy to dodatkowo okazja do zapoznania się z historią komputerowych gier RPG. To w końcu gra pamiętająca ubiegły wiek i równie kultowa jak Baldurs Gate.

33718310.review:
代入感极强，不少道具的使用过程有身临其境的探索体验。
画风诡异音乐恰到好处，有大量文本，得有点耐心。
战斗系统采用的是与现行RPG游戏截然不同的DND模式，没跑过团的一时之间很难适应。
很难想象九十年代的游戏能塑造这么完整宏大的世界观，很赞。
最后，还是说一句：
We need Chinese language.

33664410.review:
I nearly crapped my pants when I saw that PS:T was available on Steam. It is one of my all time favorites. Sets the gold standard for role playing with choices and decisions in game that actually effects gameplay and outcomes. The graphics are dated but that's not the reason to play it.  Great story for the main character  but the NPCs  also has fantastic back stories that are gradually revealed with a little patience.
I'll admit that I'm biased, probably because of nostalgia. Some people will not be able to get past the graphics and sheer amount of dialogue and descriptions. I won't judge you if you don't like. I would ask that you would give it a fair chance. It's worth it. I also suggest that if you did not like PS:ToN, the spiritual sequel, don't automatically assume you won't like this game. PS:T far longer and superior  in every way except in the graphics department, though surprisingly, not by much. While I liked PS:ToN, I didn't love it.
Try it. You'll either love it, which is most likely,, or you'll hate it.
I have never met anyone with ambiguous feelings towards Planescape: Torment.

33661542.review: Although I only have a couple hours logged on the Steam version of this game at the time of my review, I played this game all the way through multiple times on CD-ROM on my clunky old desktop back in the day. To this day, I have never played a game with a more immersive and compelling storyline than that of Planescape: Torment. It is part Choose Your Own Adventure, part mystery, and part good old fashioned point-and-click. If you want a thrill a minute and you don't like to read, then I would not recommend this game to you. But if you enjoy a good story, add this game to your collection.

33634842.review: Once I'm finished with it, might very well end up being my favourite game of all time. I just couldn't wait to post a positive review. This game only keeps getting better and better; the writing, setting and atmosphere are enchanting. The bland, unsatisfying combat is pretty much the only hurdle to get over, but it's mostly an optional part of the game anyway so it's easy to look past it. Please buy this game and in doing so, support these passionate, lovely people who have taken an old masterpiece and given it new life.

33606269.review:
If you like your RPGs more on the action side, with a complex combat system, dungeon crawling, weapon/armor hunting, then this game might not be for you. It is extremely heavy on dialogue, exploring, travelling and fetching items. It turns a lot of the tropes of the genre completely on their heads and goes for a heavy role-playing experience.

However, the universe is engrossing and the story is one of the most unusual I have ever seen in a video game. The themes are very dark, violent, depressing at times, thought-provoking. The main character's amnesia and immortality are used extremely well throughout the game, I'm now nearing the end of the first playthrough and still haven't got the whole picture of who or what The Nameless One is or what the fuck is going on.

Even if all the reviews are saying it's a masterpiece and a must-play, this is not a game for everyone. However, if you are at that point in life where you're asking yourself questions of the more philosophical nature, this game might just shake up your world view a bit.

33583958.review: Planescape: Torment has the deepest and most engrossing storyline of any cRPG. Period.

33571918.review:
I played this game back in the day from a CD-ROM way before GPUs were a thing.  

If you're into this type of RPG I can't recommend it enough.  Just the little bit that I've played since buying it again has reminded me how much I've been missing a deep and enthralling story world to romp around in.

The disc that I used to have was scratched and I could never make it past the Pillar of Skulls in the later stages of the game.  I CAN'T WAIT to find out how this game ends after nearly 20 years :D

33558214.review: Back in the days I got tired of all the reading (probably not mature enough) but now I´m nothing but excited about this jewel! This IS a fantastic game that really grows on you. In my opinion you need a couple of hours (or like.... >100) until you really begin to appreciate this amazing RPG! If you are able to forgive the sometimes lame fighting sequences and are in for the story and atmosphere - then this is a must have!

33557916.review: 非常赞的游戏。深邃而极富代入感的游戏世界让我仿佛一次又一次地重生在这个神秘的异度空间。如果说90年代以及DND的战斗系统注定不能引领时代的潮流，那么精彩绝伦的剧情设定以及生动形象的角色刻画必定能使异域镇魂曲成为永恒的经典。

33511048.review:
Одна из самых легендарных РПГ всех времен, многими считаемая эталоном. Далее краткий очерк о технической составляющей, тк. о самой игре столько обзоров, что добавить хоть что-то своё не представляется возможным.
В переиздании подправленные текстуры, удобное масштабирование, мультиплатформенность (мак и линукс), дополненные опции, практически полное отсутствие багов. Единственное, пока нет официального русского перевода (советую не ждать его выхода и воспользоваться фанатским русификатором).

Пропустили игру в своё время или желаете поностальгировать - не имеет значения. Именно сейчас настало самое лучшее время для легенды.

33470570.review:
本作的粉丝们，抱歉，时间就是你的敌人，因为这世界上没有永恒

这游戏总是被大家吹成神作，但是实际上过于老旧，除了剧本其实和现在的游戏有很大差距，特意写一个不推荐，以下是理由：

1.糟糕的战斗系统，这游戏的战斗系统真是要人命，虽然年代久远，但是这么糟糕的战斗系统也是没谁了，敌人只有点脚下的圆圈才能点中，法术永远是很难释放的，不管什么武器都是一样的速度，有人说暗黑破坏神比这游戏卖得好得多说明大家都太浮躁，我要说，这种战斗系统相比暗黑1都差十条街，拿什么卖得好？

2.这个游戏的任务没有任何提示，而且完全的无厘头！！！没有提示我们可以从对话推测出来，然而无厘头就真是没救了，举个例子，有个人要找冥河的水，结果这个任务完成方式是用霜酒杯抓鸟！再比如解谜者迷宫的进入方法任务提示是传送门，结果最终完成方法是使用一个“铁门”物品！如果不看攻略这游戏恐怕基本都会卡死在任务上，制作人自己开脑洞大家一起得发疯。

3.难以理解的难度设计，到诅咒城之前一切都还好，但是如果你之前没有在法印城地下刷怪的话，后边的任务你都做不成！第一个任务就是救酒吧老板污染巴斯的女儿，但是等级不够高的话，只要第一波没打过，卫兵回头马上杀掉他女儿，用莫提引怪都没用！而且有时候你刚一开打卫兵就把他女儿杀了，这任务设计的真是要命，强制开打，没法嘴炮，前期不刷怪就没机会做任务。

通关以后，感觉那些天天吹嘘这种90年代游戏的黑岛遗老都是一群精神病，在我看来辐射新维加斯比辐射12都好的多，无论是游戏性，任务网，还是难度设计，别听那些人吹黑岛。

异域镇魂曲这游戏就像它的名字torment一样，给人带来的只有痛苦，而且是毫无疑义的痛苦，你必须得对照着攻略书，仔细研究任何一点，还要存很多档，不然就会有恶性bug，不推荐购买

33435553.review: This game is incredible, and there are not many other words to help describe it.  Planescape: Torment has aged very well (although not graphically, but I am one that feels that is a minor issue), and provides a story rich experience that always leaves you wanting more.  If you have not treated yourself to this masterpiece, you really should.

33420227.review:
오프닝 영상 외 별다른 복선 없이 죽었다가 벌떡 깨어나셔서 날아다니는 해골 친구와 함께 대체 이게 뭔 상황인지 영문을 알아내세요. '무엇이 인간의 본성을 바꿀 수 있는가'와 '다원 우주 내 불사자로서 수 많은 현신들의 윤회, 영원, 고통, 후회, 기만, 거짓, 신념'과 같은 거창한 떡밥과 복선들 사이엔, 상당히 지겹고도 괴롭고 어디 공략이라도 읽지 않으면 게임 처음 하는 사람들 물 먹이고 벌 주는데 혈안이 된 게임 플레이들이 함께 동봉되어 있습니다. 과연 게임 제목부터가 무슨 게임인지 알려주듯, 공략집을 읽지 않으면 막히고 막히는 게임 진행에 화가 나실 수도 있습니다. 그러나 사람들이 평소 얻고자 하는 영원한 삶을 게임 소재로 써서 한편의 멋진 스토리를 만들어 낸 걸 보시면 왜 이 게임이 격찬을 받는지 잘 아시게 될 겁니다.

이미 크게 격찬 받는 게임이니 단점만 좀 적습니다.
- 공략집을 읽지 않고 하면 매우 어려울 수 있으며 게임 진행이 자꾸 끊어질 수 있습니다.
- 한국어 번역은 아주 좋지만 '나는, 당신은, 그는'과 같이 가독성에 방해되는 표현이 많아서 다듬어져야 할 필요가 보입니다.
- 게임 그래픽이 매우 올드스쿨이고 현재와 달리 너무 투박해서 감정 이입이 오히려 안 될지도 모릅니다.
- 일부 사람들은 이 게임이 지나치게 과대평가 받았다 느낄지 모릅니다.

그럼에도 불구하고 게임스토리는 한 번 쯤 꼭 확인해볼만하다고 봅니다! 
게임 살 생각은 없더라도 적어도 유튜브 코멘터리 영상이라도 보세요!

33401812.review:
나왔을 당시에는 개쩌는 게임이었다고 하지만, 지금 다시 하기에는 부담스러운 게임. 겉치레 집어치우고 말하자면 똥겜.

메이저 하지 않았던 캠페인 세팅인 플레인스케이프를 배경으로 한다는 건 신선함은 줄 수 있었겠지만, 어색함과 당황스러움도 적지 않은 던 것 같음. 적어도 나한테는 그랬음. 동료들이 무슨 종족인지, 그 종족들의 성향이나 특징같은건 둘째치고 평균적인 겉모습 조차 상상이 안 가는건 나만 그랬던 게 아닐거임.
수많은 이념들이 대립한다는 컨셉의 캠페인이긴 했지만, 나온 당시의 고정관념인 아나키스트를 멍청한 짓으로 묘사한다거나 특정 이념을 긍정적으로 묘사하려는 것 자체도 캠페인의 컨셉을 훼손하는 짓이고 말임. 아예 그럴거면 폴아웃3처럼 착한 짓만 하게 하던가. 악 성향 하면 구린 결과만 나오게 말야.

전투쪽에서는 더 할 말이 없음. 그리 길지 않은 스토리로 인한, 플레이타임 늘리기의 수단일 뿐임. 개븅신같은 전투 디자인에서 암걸렸던 인간은 나 말고도 많을거임. 데바 목따기 전에 마을에서 지붕위에 법사놈. 동료가 다 근거리고 주인공도 전사로 칼만 쓰는 백정이라 죽일수가 없었음. 제일 어려웠던 데바랑 처음 만나는 지하전던에서는 전략성이란 하나도 없는 체력, 방어력만 높은 어깨 깡패들이 수십놈 주루루 나오는데 재미도 없고 드럽게 힘듬. 옛날 겜이라고 실드를 치는것도 불가능한게, 그 당시로도 이런 전투는 쓰레기였음.

그래픽은 썩 나쁘지 않았음. 배경을 따로 모델링한게 아니라 일러스트로 떼워서 그런지 보기에는 진짜 이쁨. 처음에 더스트맨 본부에서는 좀 미묘하긴 했는데, 이곳저곳 쏘다니면 보는 맛은 있었음. 딱 보는 맛만. 이게 상호작용 가능한 오브젝트인지 아닌지, 지나갈 수 있는지 없는지, 이게 계단인지 아닌지 구분이 안 가는 병신같은 점만 빼면 썩 괜찮았음. 물론 동료들 페이스칩은 제외임. 일본풍의 그거 있잖아, 머리가 몸의 세배쯤 큰데, 눈알 두개가 얼굴의 반은 차지하는 그 모에모에체. 그런걸 바라는 건 아닌데 조금 더 이쁘게 그려주면 안 됐냐말임. 여기서 박하게 말하기는 해도 전체적인 그래픽은 그리 나쁘지 않았음.

스토리는 나쁘지 않았는데 이게 그리 빨릴만한 이야기인지 조오오오온나 의문임.
나는 이걸 인터넷에서 떠도는 '무엇이 인간의 본성을 변화시키는가' 에 대한 짧은 글-모트가 해주는 이야기 있잖아. '그게 당신의 첫 번째 소원이었소' 하는거 - 을 보고 오오오오 하면서 기대를 가지고 했는데 그딴건 별로 중요하지 않았다고.
결국 인간의 본성을 변화시키는 것에 대한 게임의 답은 주어지지 않았고, 첫 번째 인격이었떤 선한 화신놈이 말한 '후회'만 남았단 말임. 래벌 퍼즐웰도 주인공-플레이어-한테 답을 물었고, 대충 이 답 저 답해도 다 그렇습니까 하고 납득하는데, 이건 플레이어한테 생각할 거리를 줬다기 보다는 컨셉 플레이의 방점으로 놔둔거라고 봐야지. 그 전까지의 행동에 맞는 대답을 골라야 하는데 무슨 선택이야 시벌.
오히려 스토리 플롯보다는 에디트로 지력, 카리스마, 지혜를 25로 찍어두고 애들 대화 보는게 훨씬 재밌었음. 이곳 저고 쏘다니면서 각각의 이벤트에서 이런 해결법도 있었구나... 하면서 신기해 하면서 논 시간이 많았지. 플롯 자체는 그리 뛰어나지 않았음.

애초에 씨 인간의 본성을 바꾸는것 중에 게임내에서 나온 성공적인 방법이 기억을 잃는거잖아. 기억을 잃을 때 마다 다른 인격이 나오고 그게 뒈짖하면서 화신이 나오는데 그럴 때 마다 성향-본성-도 바뀌는거 보면 답 나왔네.
답은 [망치로 뒷통수 후리기]다. 기억 잃으면 됩니다. 나는 그 임신한 벽 부분에서 망치 없어서 맵 한바퀴 다 뒤졌는데, 그것만 봐도 망치가 답이란 것의 복선 아니냐 완전.



잡설이 길어졌는데 총평을 해봄.
흥미는 둘째치고 익숙해지거나 빠져들기 힘든 세계관-캠페인-에 쓰레기같은 전투, 나쁘지 않은 플롯, 썩 흥미로운 텍스트-대화-가 특징인 게임. RPG적인 즐거움인 캐릭터의 육성, 다양한 장비등을 즐기고 싶은 사람은 괴로워 할 것이고, 어드벤처적인 즐거움인 대화, 탐색, 반전 등을 좋아하는 사람한테는 그 미묘함에 미묘한 표정을 미묘한 정도로 짓게 될 것 같음.

33376412.review:
I never played the original version of Planescape Torment, but over the years I’ve often read, especially in PC Gamer, that this is an amazing game. So when the enhanced edition was released, I thought this was the perfect time to see what I’ve missed. My verdict is that PST is okay, but it doesn’t really live up to the hype.

The big negative is the combat system, which is probably the worst I’ve ever played in an RPG (yes, even worse than Dragon Age 2). Over the course of the game I think I was attacked by maybe 5 mages, and literally every other enemy (Human or monster) used melee. No ranged attacks, no special abilities. Just a basic melee attack. I don’t think the age of the game is an excuse, because I remember fighting plenty of bandit archers in Baldur’s Gate. And that limitation extends to your own party as well. I didn’t find a single ranged weapon, either as loot, or to purchase from a shop. If I missed something, it was extremely well hidden. And whilst I recruited a couple of magic users, the game uses D&D rules, which means spells have limited uses, and you have to rest your party to recharge spells. This system was fine in Baldur’s Gate where you could rest pretty much anywhere, but in PST I sometimes went hours of gameplay without being allowed to rest (most areas told me “you cannot rest here” even if there were no enemies on the map) . So even my mages were mostly used in melee. The end result is combat that is one dimensional and boring.

The big positive, is the story, characters and dialogue. I don’t really want to spoil anything, but there are several themes and ideas that I’ve never seen in a game before. Your character, the “Nameless One”, is immortal. Whenever he dies, he just resurrects a short time later. He’s also lost most of his memories, so the main quest is all about investigating his past, to discover what caused his condition. The first companion you meet is a floating, talking skull. And it just gets weirder and more interesting from there. PST is certainly unique, and this is what motivated me push through to the end.

So overall, whilst I don’t think Planescape Torment should be anywhere near a “best of ...” list because of the combat, I will give it a positive recommendation because of the story.

33351663.review:
Ich bin so hin und weg von dem Spiel.
Ich habe mich nie zuvor mit dem DSA Regelwerk auseinandergesetzt, mir war somit auch das D&D Universum nur vom Begriff etwas bekannt(?). 
Das was ich dann aber hier bekam, vom ganzen Aufbau, war etwas so intensives und das obwohl ich mit Fantasy Settings nichts anfangen kann und doch dann lieber der Story ausweiche und mich mit dem Gameplay beschäftige. Aber was ist, wenn das Gameplay im Kern sich gar nicht auf Kämpfe konzentriert sondern einfach auf Dialoge (die man LESEN MUSS, da nur einzelne Dialoge vertont wurden)? Ja dann bekommt man hier fast schon ein interaktives "Buch" mit RPG Elementen. Aber vielleicht hat man es hier dann doch perfekt geschafft das Pen & Paper-Feeling so gut wie möglich als Singleplayer Erlebnis auf den PC zu transferieren. Und man kann schon behaupten, ja es ist teils gelungen. Ich habe gefühlt 2/3 des Spiels nur gelesen und mich gefragt was ich bei den (bis zu 16(!)) Antwortmöglichkeiten und Fragen auswähle. Dann 1/6 bin ich gelaufen und der andere Rest war dann wohl mit kämpfen gespickt, welche WIRKLICH nicht zu den Stärken des Spiels gehören. Hier empfehle ich sehr das Kampfprotokoll immer auf zu haben um zu verstehen was das Spiel im hintergrund auswürfelt. Ansonsten ist das Kampferlebnis für einen genau so fragwürdig wie bei einem The Elder Scrolls: Morrowind.

Falls ihr dem Spiel nun versucht eine Chance zu geben und ihr euch etwas schwer tut, dann lege ich euch ans Herz: Gebt dem Spiel täglich eine Stunde Zeit. Stellt euch einen Timer nebenbei ein. Aber nehmt euch diese Stunde. In der Stunde nehmt ihr euch dann nicht vor alles so schnell wie möglich zu sehen. Nein. Ihr nehmt euch Zeit. Ihr guckt euch um. Drückt immer wieder mal die Leertaste um das Spiel zu pausieren, drückt dabei Tab und seht nun wie wer heißt, redet sie vielleicht auch an. Sieht wo Dinge "versteckt" sein könnten und lest einfach alles so, dass ihr nicht unter druck geratet. Falls nun der Timer mittendrin abgelaufen ist, entscheidet ihr für euch selbst: Ich breche nun ab und spiel morgen eine weitere Stunde. Oder ihr spielt einfach noch ein wenig weiter. Auch wenn's nur 10 Minuten werden, bevor die "langeweile" wieder einsetzt. Das ist aber halt in Ordnung wenn das passiert, schließlich wird man etwas anderen gewohnt sein, nach all den Jahren bombastischen Videospielkonsum, bei dem einem so viel vorgekaut wird. Man muss hier wirklich etwas lernen zurück zu treten. Und ich versichere euch, je weiter ihr kommt, desto mehr werdet ihr es lieben. Zumindest ging es mir so. 
p.s. speichert genügend, wenn ihr wirklich neu in dem Genre seid - Frust ist ansonsten (obwohl ihr nicht (richtig) sterben könnt) durchaus vorprogrammiert.

Und nun versucht endlich in dieser Welt euren Frieden zu finden.

This is an enhanced edition to what I (and quite a bit of other crpg players) consider one of the best.  The enhancements seem to be true to just being picture quality (more clarity, not new art), and better interface function.  The ability to have larger screen size and windowed play is to me wonderful.  I have encouraged my son to take the time to play this story.

This game should be played for the story, for the uniqueness of Planescape setting, and great humor (though it is dark).
This game and Fallout 1 were what I considered two of the best crpgs made.  There is a lot of "you need this item go find it" style questing, but it does not always require you go kill everyone in the room to get it, like so many of the crpgs of today do.

33162088.review:
Want to enjoy one of those amazing old RPGs you always hear about? This one, considered by many to be THE best RPG of all time, is the perfect game to start with. You get to experience a great story without a ton of that clunky combat that make some of the older RPGs hard to get into.

The story and setting are completely unique, and it's probably my favorite setting in any game that I have played. There are so many weird, cool, and funny NPCs to interact with, and so much good dialogue to read through. The enhanced edition adds quite a lot to this game, improving the UI, adding the ability to highlight interactable objects and npc's without having to pixel hunt, and an "area loot" which allows you to loot everything around you without having to click each individual corpse.

One warning, if you don't like reading, this won't be a game for you. There is a lot of it, but it is all really enjoyable.

If you enjoy story-heavy games, I highly recommend this one.

32954343.review:
I was very weary of starting this game because I'd heard so much about it. The problem with having high expectations is that very few things meet those expectations and this game was the king of high expectations. I'd tried it a few times and if I found any sort of glitch I'd just stop, honestly speaking I was looking for an excuse not to play.

Then I got myself a PS4 Pro and ended up buying and playing Psychonauts, another highly lauded game. Psychonauts was excellent, a bit dated in terms of geometry but I mean it is unquestionably one of the most unique experiences I've come across. So Planescape Torment: Enhanced Edition gets announced and I swallowed my pride and bought it as soon as I could get my hands on it.

The game for the most part ran flawlessly for me and in fact it ran flawlessly on my Ultrawide monitor which is pretty good considering a lot of major games don't do Ultrawide justice(I'm looking at you Overwatch). They also added the tab highlight function so pressing the tab key highlights everything you can click on. Then there is the area loot function which allows you to loot everything within a small radius. I made use of both and appreciated the features.

The game wasn't without it's glitches or bugs but this game still ran very well. I mean it probably takes Bethesda 3 years of patches to get to the state that this game was in during the first version, so nothing of particular note there. UI has been improved and the zoom function isn't the biggest thing in the world but it doesn't hurt either. It's basically in pretty good working order.

The graphics were largely untouched and I wasn't really sure if that was a good thing because the game looks so terribly dated. After playing the game however and without going into any spoilers, moving about a little in the world, I kind of came to the conclusion that this game was made to look the way it is as a design decision and when you venture into other parts of the world you will see the contrast. It has a sort of grimness and hopelessness that permeates the world which is interesting because fantasy titles tend to have bad guys that grin widely but you don't get a bad guy that for example that has a toe fungus or tooth decay, very real things that happened to people in the past. The game wears it's  aesthetic like a suit and the environment reaks of decay and squalor, everything kind of blends together and it can be very disorientating and confusing because you have no grasp of time or place. 

Anyway before I end up writing a review longer than the game is, it's basically an old school isometric RPG that focuses heavily on story. The writing is incredibly dense and sometimes it feels like the game is just spinning it's wheels without going anywhere. The game intentionally tries to disorientate you and it pushes and pulls on your ideas of morality and what it is to be a human being. I thought it was very well written, I mean the problem with being arty farty about things is you end up sounding arty farty. This wasn't a game trying to be intelligent but showing it's true self through shallow platitudes or a game that is trying to make you feel intelligent by giving you simple questions and then answering them definitively making you feel smart for being right. This game is a mindfuck and it's really well put together.

Reason I avoided playing this game was simply because I used to read a lot and everybody knows books have the best stories. I looked at games like classical music, it was a sort of sandbox that allowed you to act out your inclinations. I avoided most of the story heavy RPG's for a couple of decades which is why this went under my radar.

Having played it, at first I felt it was a good story. Then when I travelled the world a bit more and realised how incredibly varied it was and the clever way the developers built the levels in terms of geometry, lighting, colour palette etc it just started happening for me, this game was something special. Then the last 3 or 4 hours really sealed the deal.

I always say time is the greatest test for anything and I don't know if I will really look back in 10 or 20 years and look at this as being one of those moments where you just sort of "get it", whereas the week before you are thinking all those fancy art people are morons but this week, you are in the same boat. I've had those moments very rarely and never with a game.

This game won't be for everybody, people like different things, it'd be a very shitty world if that wasn't the case. However if you are one of those people that can't shut up about MRBTongue's BladeRunner video or you insist on carrying a copy of The Book of the New Sun everywhere you go with you just in case the unthinkable happens, you might just be one of those weirdos that has an "ohhh, so thats what that feels like" moment with this game. I'll get back to you in 10 or 20 years on whether or not this game went down as an artifact I will guard with my life but right now there's not enough I can say to do this game justice and I won't even attempt it. Try it.

32904119.review:
A veces, la vida te deja experiencias, personas, películas, libros, historias o situaciones que te marcan para siempre.

Planescape: Torment es el videojuego que más me ha marcado en los últimos años, después de pasar meses totalmente apartado del mundillo, llegando incluso a perder el interés y la fe en volver a ilusionarme por un juego.

No voy a engañaros, este texto no es objetivo. Simplemente no puede serlo. Es como intentar contarle a alguien cómo suena tu grupo favorito o como si intento describirle a uno de mis mejores amigos. De todos modos, voy a intentar ser medianamente imparcial, aunque sé que no lo voy a conseguir. Tened en cuenta que podría tirarme hablando sobre los miles de detalles que hacen este juego lo que es durante horas, y por tanto no me va a llegar el espacio para todo lo que tengo que decir. Comencemos.

Planescape: Torment es un juego de rol clásico o CRPG basado en las reglas de Dungeons & Dragons, concrétamente en las de la segunda edición. A diferencia de muchos de sus contemporáneos, este no se trata de un título centrado en el combate, si no en la conversación, la exploración y la interactividad con el entorno. Habrá combates, pero no son el punto fuerte del juego (aunque pueden llegar a ser francamente entretenidos, al fin y al cabo es un juego de D&D).

Empezamos despertando en un mortuario, no tenemos ni puñetera idea de quién somos o qué hacemos ahí. Nos acompaña una variopinta calavera, que nos leerá unas indicaciones que tenemos escritas en la espalda, y a partir de ahí todo queda en nuestras manos.

Especialmente después de ver cómo tratan al jugador los RPGs actuales, no paro de sorprenderme cómo PT es tan perfectamente orgánico. No hay ni una sola señalización, eres tú quien tienes que averiguar por dónde tienes que ir, qué tienes que hacer y cómo. Tienes que esforzarte en hablar con todos los personajes del escenario, prestar atención a lo que te rodea y a lo que te cuentan y decidir cual es tu próximo paso. No os voy a contar mentiras: Aquí vas a pasar la mayor parte de tu tiempo leyendo y pensando. No suena muy divertido, ¿Verdad?

Lo cierto es que podría no serlo si no fuese porque estamos ante un guión que está considerado uno de los mejores de la historia de los videojuegos. Personalmente, no puedo nombrar uno mejor. De hecho, diría que deja en ridículo a guiones de otras disciplinas. La presentación tanto de los personajes principales como de los secundarios es fantástica, así como sus trasfondos y evolución. La trama principal te atrapa desde el segundo uno. Las subtramas son variadas, profundas y, en ocasiones, sorprendentes. El universo está descrito con todo lujo de detalle y aumenta la inmersión hasta límites insospechados. Por si esto fuera poco, la historia principal cuenta con ciertos tintes filosóficos que rara vez son implementados adecuadamente en los videojuegos, ya que los guionistas tienen a ser extremadamente pretenciosos.

En definitiva, el guión y especialmente la misteriosa trama principal, consiguen atraparte y tenerte pegado a la pantalla leyendo e investigando durante horas. Nunca en mi vida había pasado una noche entera sin dormir, viendo el amanecer desde el ordenador, solo para ver cómo termina un juego. Hacía años que no era capaz de aguantar ningún videojuego más de cuatro horas seguidas, y este lo compré un lunes a la 1AM y el jueves a las 8AM lo había terminado con 41 horas en total.

En cuanto a lo más puramenet jugable, en Torment, casi todo lo que hacemos importa. Esto es porque nuestro alineamiento, o moral, por llamarlo de alguna manera, se modifica con casi cada decisión que tomemos, lo cual va a tener consecuencias a diversos niveles (Cómo nos ven ciertos personajes o facciones, por ejemplo). Mencionar también que gracias a estas decisiones, PT es altamente rejugable, más aún si añadimos el hecho de que hay tres clases y solo nos conviene utilizar una por cada run.  

Aunque como ya he dicho, el combate no es excesivamente importante, nuestros atributos sí que lo son, pues desbloquean numerosas opciones, especialmente en conversación (Cuanta más sabiduría e inteligencia tengáis, mejor). Esto no es una aventura gráfica y el roleo tiene una presencia brutal, así que no os dejéis engañar por la menor importancia que se le da a las peleas.

En cuanto aspectos técnicos, esta edición trae un buen remozado a la interfaz y añade algunas opciones, dejando el resto del juego intacto, lo cual se agradece. En el plano artístico, Torment no defrauda, con localizaciones variadas y atípicas, multitud de modelos para los personajes, detallados escenarios... Sí que es cierto que las áreas no son tan grandes como las de otros RPGs de la época, pero yo prefiero la calidad sobre la cantidad. La banda sonora es un gran punto a favor, con temas que se te quedarán para siempre por aparecer en situaciones que no vas a olvidar. Encaja perfectamente con la atmósfera y sientes hasta el impulso de escuchar algunos de los temas cuando terminas la historia.

Y para terminar voy a tirar de mi lado más pasional y subjetivo:

Los videojuegos son como las personas. Hay un montón. Muchas son auténtica basura, otras son repetitivas y están plagadas de clichés, y también hay un buen puñado que merecen la pena y te hacen pasar buenos ratos.

Pero a veces encuentras alguna persona que puede llegar a donde otros no pueden. Esa persona con la que hablarías durante horas sin cansarte. Recuerdas cuándo y cómo os conocisteis y le cuentas todo lo que te pasa.

Pues Planescape: Torment es su equivalente en el mundo virtual. Una experiencia repleta de personajes, situaciones, lugares, historias y leyendas tan memorables que no vas a poder deshacerte de ellas. Algo que ocupa tu cabeza desde que lo empiezas hasta que lo terminas y, una vez que lo haces, sientes esa felicidad de haber jugado a uno de los mejores  RPGs de la historia.

Atentamente, un fanboy.

10/10

32762752.review:
[h1] "What Can Change the Nature of a Man?" [/h1]

*Webster's New English Dictionary*
Role-playing Game
[i]-noun	[/i]
   1. Planescape Torment

I have lived my whole life up to this point thinking that Baldur's Gate 2 was the best RPG story there is. Before the Enhanced Edition went on sale, I had just played the original version of Planescape Torment for the first time, 18 years after release. I have no excuse for waiting this long to play it, but it doesn't matter, this is a timeless classic.

This is the very definition of RPG. In the 90s, when RPGs were mostly focused on gameplay, Planescape Torment dared to make an RPG with a heavy focus on narrative. That should sound familiar to modern day gamers, because Planescape Torment is the model that has been followed by almost every RPG that has been made since. But few have done it as well. Especially considering the fact that while this games' focus is on story, it retains fantastic gameplay, almost as good as Baldur's Gate 2 or Icewind Dale, its videogame half brothers.

Most of us *know* what it's like to wake up on cold stone with a splitting headache after a night out cracking too many cold ones with the boys. Add brilliant dark-fantasy lore and some dark humor to the worst hangover you've ever had and you get the premise for the story in Planescape Torment, except it's even worse. Instead of your bathroom floor, you rise from the dead in a mortuary, to a romantic poet that happens to be a floating skull (like I said, morbid, dark humor) at the center of the multiverse, in Sigil, the city of doors, that has portals to every plane of existence you've ever heard of.

With no knowledge of who you were in life, no knowledge of your own name, and a cast of bizzare companions, none of which are human, though some of them possibly used to be, you must learn secrets of your past, discover who you are and where you came from, and who the scumbag is who decided to curse you, steal your mortality, and leave you for dead. 

It may seem like it's going to have a predictable ending, especially if you're familar with other famous stories about amnesiacs, (such as KoToR, or the Bourne films and Memento) Let me help you by saying this game will end in ways that you don't expect, and like any good RPG, it has multiple endings, based on your actions. It's got great gameplay, DnD party-based strategy that comes close to being as good as Baldur's Gate 2, and it's loaded with great quests, and the way you solve even the tiniest of fetch quests could become one of the many *Regrets* that you will have by the end of the game.

The Witcher 3 can Pike off, in comparison to the writing in Planescape Torment, Witcher 3 sounds like a children's story. And if that isn't enough to convince you, *know* that this game has vastly better gameplay too.

In *knowing* that this game is more of an interactive novel, you will *know* that this game is for stimulating pleasures of a psychological nature, rather than pleasures of the physical. And in *knowing* these teachings, your video game taste will become stronger.

The flames grow within the old masterpieces like Planescape Torment, now that it has made it to Steam, finally. If you're waiting to play this game, have patience, and *know* that time is not your enemy, forever is. Whether you would die to play a great RPG with top-notch writing, or you would only feign death, you *must* play this game... while you still can. The Circle must come to a close. Once it does, will this game really *matter* to you? It will matter to you more than life. Many games have been played across many lifetimes, but none have writing has good as this one.


It's dark, it's gripping, it's deep, it's philosophical,
 It's Planescape Torment.

[h1] Pros	[/h1]
-story 11/10 
Best writing the gaming industry has to offer.
-gameplay 9/10 
complicated, replayable, dynamic. Most fights will force you to strategize, and the spell effects are mesmerizing by 90s graphics' standards. Some spells even get their own cut-scene. Few modern gameplay systems can boast of that level of artistic detail.
-world 11/10 
The best fantasy setting there is, it's got richer lore than Middle-earth, and it's as interesting as it is weird.
-atmosphere/immersion 9/10 
Despite being an old-top-down and more of an interactive book, somes sequences in this game will make you actually *feel* like you are on another plane of existence, because of the sound effects, (for its time) gorgeous graphics, and a good soundtrack.

[h1] Cons	[/h1]

-you can't form a full party of 6 for most of the game, and that certainly was disappointing and it annoyed me, but that falls into the category of nit-picking, and is is really all I can think of in the way of "cons."
-Side-content 0/10
There isn't any really. The side-quests in Sigil count as part of the main story because many of them have an impact on your character recovering knowledge and memories. Everything is a part of only one long, but fantastic, linear main-quest. This is the only reason this game remains secondary to the few RPGs that are better, such as Baldur's Gate 2, because There is no room for '2' in the world of 1's and 0's. 

Don't question if this is the best RPG ever made, because there is no place for 'mayhap' in a house of trues and falses. So to avoid "mayhap", you may *know* that this is certainly one of the best, even though it is not THE best.

To the upcoming BioWare or Obsidian RPG that will hopefully have as good story as this game... "I shall wait for you in Deaths halls, my love."

And to the million-life question "What can change change the nature of a man?" The answer is, this game.

10/10 
-and in case you were wondering, this review has 100 subtle references to quotes from the game, that you will recognize once you have done yourself a favor and played it.

32670592.review:
Originally released in 1999 by Interplay Entertainment and Black Isle Studios, Planescape: Torment is a legendary cult classic among RPG enthusiasts. Picked up later by Beamdog, the same publisher/developer responsible for the outstanding Enhanced Editions of other classic RPGs such as Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale, Planescape: Torment has received the same Enhanced Edition treatment, complete with a remastered soundtrack, native 4K support, and a few more modern features to make gameplay a bit more user friendly.

To avoid spoiling any part of this bewitching tale, only a very brief synopsis of the plot basics will be included in this review. You take on the role of The Nameless One, a possibly immortal man whom has awoke with a severe case of amnesia in a grim, zombie-infested mortuary. He is soon approached by a sarcastic, yet witty, floating skull named Morte,  who helps to guide The Nameless One through his confused state, but can this seemingly harmless companion be trusted? Unsure of his past, his name, or even his purpose, The Nameless One and the skull then set off on their ultimate quest of attempting to restore The Nameless One's memory, and figure out just what the foreboding, instruction-like tattooed scrawls on his back mean.

The game takes place within the Planescape multiverse of the Dungeons and Dragons universe, a setting that entails various planes of existence; though do not let that deter you if you know little to nothing of the classic board game. Planescape: Torment does an absolutely stunning job in conveying both basic and detailed information about the vast and seemingly endless world that it takes place in; I went in with virtually no knowledge of this realm, and I feel as though I could now write a book on it. However, if getting to know the lore so in-depth is not your thing, a great feature of this game is being able to sink your teeth into it as shallow or as deep as you prefer.

It's true that you can lose yourself for hours at a time when becoming immersed in just the setting of Planescape: Torment alone, but each of the characters are equally as memorable, and most of them have intricate backgrounds. During your long and difficult journey, you will meet many, many people; some of which will become companions if given the chance, others are there simply for conversation sake, and some you will run optional errands for. This again boils down to how deep you wish to dive into this adventure, to which it is whole-heartedly recommended to let go of reality completely and sink all the way to the bottom of the countless fathoms of this story.

If you choose to totally immerse yourself, you can expect to get anywhere from 40-50 hours out of this title, though it also depends on how quickly you read. It's best to not go in to the game expecting an RPG full of battles, but rather to expect a ratio of about 90% reading, 10% fighting. Most of the combat is reserved for the much later portion of the story, and even then it's still not a primary focus. There are boss battles, but the combat and loot system are primitive at best, a bit boring at worst, though this feature should not be your deciding factor on whether or not you decide to play Planescape: Torment; simply be aware that this is a heavily story based title. Despite a lacking combat system, you are able to choose between three classes for The Nameless One; mage, fighter, and thief. As for any RPG, leveling up and attribute points are also included.

Aside from all of that, in typical Dungeons and Dragons manner there is a karma system. It's not overly complex by any means, being comprised of the Lawful, Chaotic, Neutral, Good, and Evil rankings. At any given time, depending on your actions and interactions, you can be Lawful Neutral, Lawful Good, Lawful Evil, Chaotic Neutral, Chaotic Good, or Chaotic Evil. If you're new to this kind of karma system, it's best to let either the game or a search engine explain it to you, but it's quite basic. Your overall karma level will determine how people around you react to you, including your companions, so it does make a difference. As well, the companions that you keep with you throughout the game will make a difference in some dialogue and interactions, especially during the end game content.

There are hundreds, if not a thousand or more, unique dialogue interactions. The possible and neigh infinite conglomeration of their branches means that replay value here is extremely high. Not only do you talk to dozens of people throughout the campaign, it's also good to speak with your companions from time to time to get their input on things; they may even reveal more of their backstory to you over time, if you treat them well enough. There are also a couple of different endings to attain, and even replaying the ending alone has a ton of story-based benefits. While on the subject, the last dying breaths of the game are just as renowned as the rest of the title, and it fills the player with a deep sense of completion and satisfaction no matter the final outcome.

So, should you play Plansecape: Torment? Beyond any possible shadow of a doubt, absolutely yes. That is, so long as you want to experience one of the best and most detailed fictional stories ever written. It's a tale that your mind will keep summoning back to you while you're working, stuck in traffic, or completing other mundane tasks. The characters are unforgettable, and even if you happen to take a couple weeks off to play something else in the meantime you will not have forgotten a single thing about this title by the time that you return; unlike many other RPGs where you have no clue where you left off at, it's just that remarkable. There is not enough praise in the world for Planescape: Torment, and it's certainly not an experience that you should rob yourself of.

32574958.review:
It's still a goddamn ride.

Definitely the weirdest of the Infinity Engine games, both in terms of setting and gameplay, it's probably also one of the most memorable. Despite using the AD&D ruleset, it's honestly got more in terms with a visual novel or a dating sim than a conventional RPG(in the sense of being incredibly dialogue-heavy and the classic RPG elements being relatively superficial).

You're not questing to find the longsword with the biggest plus, instead you're on a quest of identity, and you have plenty of decisions you can make just for fun and out of the goodness of your heart(doing some food-tasting at a Hive market, for instance). It's relatively short, but well-written, and it just oozes charm and character. The shortness is really its only flaw, as some character arcs feel like they're executed a bit too rapidly, and other characters felt like theirs were left on the cutting room floor(FFG and Annah, for instance).

It's one of those games that let you be evil. Like REALLY evil, not just cartoonishly evil, and it'll make you feel like a dick if you try it. It's also one of the few games that often let you have multiple options for saying the same thing... just so you can be truthful or lying about it. Usually the only impact of that(assuming you have the charisma to pull off a convincing lie) is a change to your alignment(which *mostly* just functions as something cosmetic).

Despite the flaws and the fact that they tried to make it work in an engine that was most certainly made for something completely different, it's still good, it's still memorable, and I'd recommend it to anyone.

(though I do wish the Enhanced Edition would've fixed that one bug in one of the game's final areas that allowed you to get mobbed and mauled by enemies during a cutscene if you didn't clear them out properly first)

Give it a try, see what you think.

I played through this for the first time with the EE edition. In my opinion it is one of the best game stories ever written, also one of the most surreal ones. It is the big quest for an immortal character to find and get back his mortality with lots of weird characters you meet and places you visit. If you are looking for a more accessable game of this genre, maybe try one of the modern ones first (like Tyranny), but I can definitely recommand Planescape Torment for everyone who wants to experience uncommon stories with occasional philosphical questions to think about. 31889683.review:
This game is one of my favorite cRPG's of all time. I was a huge fan of Bioware and Black Isle back in the day and I bought all of their isometric games and their expansions. I got Planescape: Torment as soon as it came out. I played P:T so much that I managed to scratch the third disk and the game would no longer load after a point. I'm very glad to have come across this version not least because I'm on Ubuntu nowadays but I don't have to freakin' change disks anymore! Let's get to the review!

So is the Enhanced Edition really different from the original game? No, it isn't: it tidies up the interface, adds some nice things to game play, such as zooming and an 'autoloot' that is really more like a loot-all-corpses-in-your-immediate-area ability that you can toggle on and off. It looks like the graphics were also tidied up as was the quality of the character sounds. That's pretty much it for the really noticeable aspects. Thankfully, the rest of the game has not been changed as far as I can tell.

For those who haven't tried this game yet, what is this all about? Planescape is an oddity because it takes place in a world, or rather a series of worlds, where belief and will are the most important forces. What are the worlds? They are the heavens, the hells and everything in between. Not only is this game about belief and will but it also heavily involves death/life, memories, regret and of course torment.

The great positives of the game are the characters, the story, the secrets, freaky people and non-people, the weird objects, the zones of the game, the art and the really unique feel. It's a glorious game where most of the time is spent exploring and learning about Planescape and the odd situation the main protagonist finds himself in rather than beating the snot out of monsters. 

The characters your protagonist picks up along his way are all unique and a little bit zany. They have unique items, some of them have unique abilities and they have some of the most developed character stories I've ever come across in any RPG. They also interact often with each other as much as with the main character. 

Though there are only four classes available (mage, fighter, priest and thief), there are both dual class and multi-class options. The classes have also been tweeked to fit the P:T environment: for example mages have the ability to buff much like priests do and there are spells in this game that don't exist in 'canonical' 2nd edition AD&D. 

There is a lot of replay value from trying out good, evil, neutral, chaotic and lawful choices and of course the different factions that exist in Sigil, the main city. The main character can also grow in several different ways that also adds to replay value. That's the thing about Nameless One: he really grows!

The negatives are the fact that there are only four classes available, which is rather limiting. The weapon and armor choices are also rather limited. Want to put a sword on Nameless One if he's a basher? Well tough, you can't!

There are some bugs that have been carried over from the original. If you're not careful, you can mess up your game like I did 4 hours in. I left an important item on the ground (a note that I mistook for an unimportant note because they share the same icon), quit game at some point, reloaded, went back to get it when I realized my mistake and discovered it was gone. There are also some old bugs that cause some scripted stuff to get stuck and reqiuire a reboot of the computer. Fortunately it only happened once so far to me since playing this version but I remember this happening back in the day too. 

Lastly, this is only single player unlike the other Infinity Engine games so you're roped into the NPCs the game gives you though there is a little bit of choice in that there are more NPCs than party slots available. If you want to play with a buddy, you're out of luck, Fortunately, unlike in the BG games, none of the NPCs are duds: they're all pretty good at what they do.

What are the neutral aspects? The combat, which always seemed to me like an afterthought though it still takes up a good portion of the gameplay time. Compared to the BGs and IWD, the combat is rather uninspiring in P:T. Is it the spells, the limited classes, the balance between the party and the enemies, the available abilities? I was never sure what was lacking. If you are the sort of player who loves tactical combat, this game will probably disappoint you. I found P:T to always be the easiest of the isometric AD&D games to beat combat-wise and it required the least amount of pondering out strategies to keep everyone from dying quickly. At the same time, it's not totally awful either.

The other annoyance for me is inventory management. BG2 had the best options with scroll cases and gem pouches. In the beginning of this game, you'll be picking up a lot of things to sell and it's a lot of clicking and moving stuff around in bags and such when you're trying to make a few initial coppers.

Overall, I give this version of P:T a 9/10, just like I would the original. The point off is for the bugs and annoying features that the original shipped with as described above and that haven't been gotten rid of. I recommend this game to anyone who likes a great story in a unique environment.

Summary:
Pros - story, secrets, world and zones, character stories and development, weird items, art, feel, decent UI cleaned up by Beamdog, good replay value.
Cons - limited class and NPC party choices, limited gear choices, bugs/glitches.
Neutral - meh combat with little strategy required, inventory management.

31835554.review:
Planescape Torment was a game that I initially missed playing when growing up. I loved similar games like the Icewind Dale and Baldurs Gate series thoroughly and almost instantly picked up this remastered gem when I saw it got re-released.

I've oft times stumbled upon others praising this game as "the father of all isometric top-down tactical rpgs", and having completed the game now, I couldn't agree more - It's simply fantastically written with meaningful choices, companions that make you *want* to talk to them and hear their backstory. In my first playthrough I'm fairly sure that I missed at least one possible companion, which just makes me even more curious for my coming second playthrough.

Another great thing is the fact that the game doesn't hold your hand. It can be brutally hard and the quests only vaguely suggest where to go next, which to me is a good thing, because it actually made me having to peruse through my journal again and revisit dialogue for any hints that I might have missed. Some side rumour-based quests don't even show in the journal - those you have to explore all on your own. I played as a mage, so the combat was challenging at times, but the unique mechanic around dying made it doable in some clutch situations. I will try the fighter the next time I visit this unqiue and beautifully crafted world.

31826916.review:
This is the only Game i've ever played that lives up to the term "Role Playing." I cannot give this game a high enough Rating. It is my all-time favorite.  If you thought Mass effect 2 gave you real complex and throughtful choices with real sotry rewards, this game will blow you away. 

But let's start with the Cons
+ This is a very old game, and it shows. The Graphics are Primitive. The Game-play is not well balanced, and there is a very steep learning curve. Many Players will want to look up guides or walkthroughs to help with this complex and sometimes unintuative Game. 
+ The game is definately on the darker more philisophical side and it's extreemely wordy. If you don't want to sit down and read a novel, this is not the game for you. 
+ The game-play can be difficult. It's a  turn-style combat with a running clock (final fantasy 7 meets Starcraft) It simulates real time, and expects you to hit pause constantly in order to acomplish anything.
+ The game is a 2d top down squad based adventure game. Think Icewind dale, or baulders gate, but it's one of the most primitive in the bunch. Small views, that stay close to the characters, and pixilated Sprites.


The Good stuff
+ This was the first game to invent an in-game reason for why you come back to life after you die. Simply said, you play an imortal who is trying to find out whyhe can't die. When you do loose a life, you simply wake up where all the bodies are dumped.
+ The story is incredible, and cannot be fully explored in less than three playthroughs. There are several completely differnt endings, an increidibly detailed and interesting word, and more secrets to find than were inside pandora's box.
+ The writing is all about the nature of humanity, and phlosophy. 
+ There are real consequences to your actions, and your character can truly choose to be good, evil, reckless or cautious with real in game benefits. The  tracks your personality choices, and gives you differnt results if you play a character with a consistant personality or instead just do whatever you feel like at the time somewhat roandomly.
+ The Plot of the game is extreemely compelling. At every stage of the game you have a clearly defined goal, a fun new place to explore, new people to get to know, and your own peronsal plot is heavily tied into the events of the world. You never feel disconnected from the setting, even though your character is clearly lost and alone.
+ The coolest powers, spells and characters i'v ever met in any game. Everythign is flavorful, and not quite like you'd expect from a fantasy game.

But the real rason to play this game? 
I've never played anything else that even comes close to making me feel like i had a real effect on the NPCs, and the Game world, while also havng the freedom to be exactly the kind of badass i wanted to be. I can summon the powers i want, and do the things i want to do.

I paid full price. It was worth more. 9/10

31674160.review:
15 hours in - first time playing.

3 often repeated  points stand out. 2 true 1 false.

1."the writing is some of the best in VG history."

That is true.  I'm not a big in game reader -for example -  I skip 90% of those items called "books" in rpgs -In good games I  learn a detailed and rich plot  from gameplay and conversations. OK, but in this game the writing is so tight that I try and read it all. The  journals (yours and others)  really adds to the game.  And adds vauable information. Also,  t's not Wall of text. The writing is  very efficient. The writers constantly detail the freakish appearance of the NPCs you meet  along the way and I never click through. I read it every time (except merchants).

2. "The combat suks" -  So far 15 hours in - it doesnt. It's not hard thinking. It's kiting around - I'm a fighter build and I put nothing in wisdom(my real life also) so for me it should really be borin.g - all I seem to do is fight - but it's not boring. It makes you feel strong. It bonds you with your commpanions. It's fun to slaughter a dozen thugs(in game) . It's fun to let them run away or click on them and watch your toons auto chase them around the map. And some fights are hard even with the kiting tricks.  It's not deep deep combat. But it's not horrible either. And you can avoid a lot of it.  The combat banter is fun and  sound effects are good.  There are no 15 20 minute battles. They finish quick.
After 30 hours i may change my mind. I'll  see. Also there is a nice simple  weapon/magic/theiving system that  works for the game. 

3.   "it is mostly for the story/writing ." - I agree. The game mechanics and art  add and are sometimes interwoven into the writing. They never take away from immersion. The drawings of the main protaganists and their sprites are great and work well with the writing - but the writing is the star.The witing is what drives you forward. And again, I usuallly don't read in game journals/books - unless I get stuck and run out of ideas. This game is different. 

An extra few observation: the world is  original - not a bunch of high fantasy(?) cliches like BG12(i love) or apocalyptic cliches like FO2(I love almost as much as BG) - both of which I played first in 2015(no nostalgia in this review) . And planetscape is not  abstract and philosophical (unless you want it to be). It's a game with an original dark comic feel and it's fun.   
The interactions with your companions are all entertaining. Also humorous. Characters are  original and  you really want to know more about them no spoilers.

31641883.review:
Даже не знаю для кого и чего обзор писать, хотя очень хочется. Наверное, просто ради плюса к  рейтингу игры. Причастные и так в курсе что почем, а мимокрокодилы все равно в страхе закроют страницу, не узрев йоба-графония. Так что не буду лишний раз разливаться соловьем о тех аспектах, которые сделали игру легендарной. Больше tech report будет.

Итак, по пунктам:

1) Больше никаких рукоблудий с HD патчами. Все пройдено в 4к без малейших затыков, кроме единственной локации (беременная аллея), которая почему-то решила выделиться своими квадратными пропорциями

2) Нативная версия для GNU/Linux, за что спасибо бимдогам, которые традиционно делают не только для шендоуза. Оставляем кое-как допиленный GemRB позади.

3) Багов - сущий мизер. Ломающих так и вовсе не замечено за несколько прохождений. Однажды проскочил воскресший Мар, которого я перед этим порезал за все дела, однажды гавкнулся квестовый диалог у шлюхи напротив бара "Горящий труп". Ну и все, собсна.

4) В самой игре никаких ломающих изменений. Все довольно бережно провернуто, с уважением к эпохальному труду. Добавили только немного всяких удобств, вроде панели быстрого лута, подсветки и прочего.

5) Официального перевода пока нет. Обещают, но обещанного три года ждут, как известно (пламенный привет БГ2). Неофициальный существует и вполне играбелен.

6) Ачивки и карточки. Не то чтобы то, что волнует ЦА подобных игр, но все равно приятно. 

Ну и что в сумме? Играл я в планетку после откровенно убогого и графоманского тормента. Который стоит втрое дороже и не обладает и сотой долей всей винрарности и обаяния оригинала. Это определенно одна из ключевых игр жанра, которую облагородило вменяемое и бережное переиздание. Придраться всегда найдется к чему при желании, но здесь это откровенно неуместно. Так что если у вас есть вкус в игорах, но до сих пор нет Planescape: Torment: Enhanced Edition в библиотеке, то смело берите ее и погружайтесь в историю Безымянного.

31602792.review:
When it was first launched, in December 1999, Planescape: Torment was praised for its plot, dialogue and colourful characters, but sold practically nothing and was seen as a commercial failure. Which is a shame, because it might well have the best story of any RPG ever.

Built on the Infinity engine, which should be familiar to those who have played Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale, Torment's gameplay revolves around a party led by an amnesiac undying zombie called The Nameless One as he tries to regain his memories and find out who he is. The game takes the party through the crazy setting of Planescape, where anything can be a portal to another plane, and sees them talk to, fight, and die to the denizens of various worlds they pass through. However, most of the game happens in a city central to the planes, called Sigil.

Dialogue is built on the classic RPG formula of dialogue trees, where saying something unlocks another option, or only gives several different options. Nothing significant there, except for the fact that everything that falls under writing is heavily detailed and verbose, which really helps transport the player into Planescape. Totalling several hundreds of thousands of words, you can rest assured that the game will tell you a long story.

Combat is Torment's weakest part, best skipped. In the case that it does come to blows however, there are no penalties for losing a fight, since death is only a temporary issue. While combat at the start of the game is more of a chore, things improve later on as you gain more experience, spells, or tattoos, which are the game's replacement for armour. Moreover, the variety of party members will usually make just about any fight completely trivial later on.

The last thing one should draw attention to is the very nature of Planescape, which is shaped by belief. The more people believe in a certain god, the more powerful they grow, for instance. This can be exploited on a more personal level as well, for instance helping an ecologically-distressed man by believing that the trees around Sigil can live and asking your party members to believe in such a thing as well, with the effect of said trees starting to bloom. Otherwise, as stated before, any enclosed space can be a portal, and every portal has a key, which can be anything from a happy thought to a crooked fingerbone to a little dance that you do. These portals can take one to any other plane existent in the AD&D cosmogony, and in some cases in the game, they do.

A small flaw of the game is that a lot of the dialogue can only be seen by a Nameless One who is especially intelligent and wise, so if one wishes to uncover as much as they can through dialogue, they're kind of forced to play Mage by the game, which may not sit well with some.

The Enhanced Edition of the game has really enhanced it, adding many convenient and, in some cases, necessary changes, for ease of play, like getting rid of the action wheel of the original. However, if one is unhappy with any of the changes made, or even with all of them, they can opt to play the original game, with nothing added to it. Beamdog has outdone themselves this time.

In the end, Planescape: Torment is a beautiful story under the guise of an excellent RPG, bar the combat. You buy this game if you want to encounter deep, complex characters, like a *good* Succubus, a floating smack-talking skull, or the very essence of justice animating a suit of armour. You buy this game if you enjoy listening to a load of lore about one of the more outlandish D&D settings. You buy this game if you feel like reading something, but would also like to have some company along the way.

31550285.review:
PT:EE is a game that I would recommend as an essential game to play for anyone who claims to be a fan of video games, let alone RPGs. However, it is seminal for gamers in the same way that The Birth of a Nation (1915) is seminal for fans (and creators) of film; no one sane in 2017 considers The Birth of a Nation an excellent film. In the same way, I would not call PT:EE an excellent game. In fact, its execution is indicative of why modern (AAA) developers shy away from the classic CRPG model in favor of The Witcher, Fallout and Mass Effect (although Obsidian appears willing to almost single-handedly bear the burden).

Allegedly, the OST is remastered. Perhaps not the fault of Beamdog, but Interplay, the majority of the OST is derived from the melody of the Main Theme, which is good, yet merely builds up momentum without reaching the euphonious apex promised by the anticipatory tunes. I might have liked the music of Sigil, the city where TNO spends most of his time, if I were not hearing it for about thirty hours. While it and the Mortuary inflicted listlessness upon me, I became annoyed with Sigil Battle, which is actually a good song the longer it plays, but the number of hostile low-level thug enemies triggers it too frequently (Curst Battle is better anyway). Because of the disproportionate amount of time I spent in Sigil, I failed to notice that each character has unique music until their themes are played near the game’s conclusion. Annah’s theme, while as beautiful as Deionarra’s, is incongruous with her character. I enjoyed the theme of Fall from Grace as featured in her “brothel” as well as the music in the Civic Festhall; I wish I could have heard more, but my time was limited in those locations.

The most notable quality-of-life improvement that Beamdog has implemented in PT:EE is the the ability to scale the resolution to 4k, though I settled for 1080p. Readers should take note of the screenshots throughout this review (click to ; fully zoomed out, the sprites are high res, but tiny. On my 18″ laptop, I found myself straining to identify assets like NPCs, items, or interactive objects. After about ten hours of frustration, I fumbled around the keyboard looking for relief, and found the TAB key, which activates a highlighter. This is apparently a new feature, for it is missing in the key bindings listed in the options menu—a crucial oversight by Beamdog. Such are the consequences of augmenting the game’s native resolution of 640×480 by a factor of four.

What could have benefited most from a “remaster” is the actual gameplay. Fans of Planescape: Torment might play the role of apologist, claiming that those looking for action are doing so in the wrong place. They are correct. PT:EE limits the robust character class systems that made D&D famous to simply fighter, thief, and mage—the former of which the player begins, while the latter is considered the “preferred” play style, not because of the spell selection, but because high intelligence and wisdom are valuable commodities in a game that lacks any challenging enemy encounters. I never lost a single fight, utilizing a simple “surround and pound” strategy of selecting all my party members and clicking on one enemy at a time, even with characters who are supposed to be lacking in martial ability. The neutering of the combat is an unorthodox method to dissuade players from choosing the path of violence as a resolution. At any rate, PT:EE places heavy emphasis on roleplay, providing players with clever, civil solutions to conflict (unless players choose to depict TNO as a jerk).

The pacing in PT:EE is dreadful. I found the emergent gameplay in System Shock Enhanced Edition effective because it allows players to explore multiple floors of the Citadel Station while keeping players focused through the implementation of corridors. I burned 10-15 hours just to map my way around Sigil in PT:EE, and by the time I had mapped and could navigate the locations, I was thoroughly bored. And it is not as if Sigil is huge, as it is made up of roughly six screens—eight if one includes the Lower Ward and Cleric’s Ward as roughly the same (and I do). It is the story that makes PT:EE famous, and true to the tradition of the CRPG format, there is lots and lots and LOTS of reading. The multiple sophisticated speech trees hidden through interacting with every NPC with a unique name inevitably becomes a sunken cost investment. I would have loved to have spent more time mediating the war between the Dead Nations and legion of Cranium Rats, or being mentally stimulated by the women of the Brothel for Slaking Intellectual Lusts, or experiencing the epiphanies provided by the sensorums of the Civic Festhall, or actually “scaping” planes, but such activities, including the acquisition of the last three characters in my party, are limited to the last quarter of the game, and there is not enough of it to justify the drag. While the narrative payoff within the Negative Material Plane is massive and ultra cool, I do not believe that its excellence justifies the first three-fourths of the game’s aimlessness. I would have preferred to experience Planescape: Torment as a visual novel.

Full Review at [url=http://www.geeksundergrace.com/gaming/review-planescape-torment-enhanced-edition/]Geeks Under Grace[/url]
